report_title: Industry Report on Fluid Power Equipment Distributors
executive_summary: Fluid power equipment distributors have faced volatile conditions following swings in the economy stemming from the pandemic. Fluid power equipment has a variety of uses, allowing distributors to diversify their client base. This prevents major swings in revenue if a single downstream market is affected. The pandemic hindered the manufacturing and mining sector, generating the bulk of revenue as businesses were forced to operate at limited capacity or shut down temporarily. The residential construction market was a saving grace for distributors, preventing companies from exhibiting a major slump in revenue. As the economy recovered and businesses reopened, the need for equipment rebounded slightly. Overall, revenue is expected to decline at a CAGR of 1.2% over the five years to 2023.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Volatile Conditions Shift the Need for Equipment
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Fluid power equipment is used in various downstream industries, preventing significant swings in revenue if an individual market is declining. Even so, the pandemic caused most markets to slump, significantly hindering sales. Many mining and manufacturing industries closed temporarily or operated at a limited capacity. A lone bright spot was using fluid power equipment in residential construction as low-interest rates spurred homebuilders to take on new projects.

Following the pandemic, declining sectors recovered, bolstering the need for fluid power equipment. A massive uptick in oil prices expanded the market for equipment to help with drilling efforts. The pandemic accelerated e-commerce platforms because of stay-at-home orders, causing an increased reliance on the internet. This gave distributors an advantage against direct-to-manufacturer purchasing, as manufacturers have a limited online web presence.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Larger Companies Are On The Move
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Distributors generally record lower profit levels because of the nature of their work. Even so, larger and more prominent companies that secure exclusive contracts with upstream manufacturers may be able to procure the inventory at a lower cost, earning a higher markup when selling it. Distributors may secure such agreements in exchange for heavily marketing the manufacturer's product. While profit is low for the most part, large companies continue to engage in heavy acquisition activity to expand, as smaller companies are unable to keep up with challenging conditions and rising competition.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Industry Machinery Continues to be Used
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: As the economy fully recovers, downstream markets will resume activities at full strength, facilitating renewed spending on industrial investments like fluid power equipment. Rising corporate profit will allow markets to replace existing equipment with new ones or upgrade parts and accessories to keep systems running smoothly. As inflation gradually contracts, the Federal Reserve is expected to reduce interest rates, causing the cost of borrowing to fall. This will encourage markets to up their investment in equipment.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: A Shift in the Energy Markets
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Oil prices are set to fall drastically, following massive spikes shortly after the pandemic. This will reduce significant spending from oil drilling companies as they cut costs following reduced revenue. Even so, fluid power equipment is essential for drilling and helps businesses easily operate heavy machinery. While revenue is set to dip in these markets, it will be minimal. As prices return to pre-pandemic levels, distributors will better understand the market and adjust their inventory accordingly to ensure they do not overstock on extra equipment.

As renewable energy continues to gain popularity, distributors will shift their focus to providing for those markets. Wind and solar power companies will be an essential target market as hydraulic systems are used in wind turbines and pneumatic systems are implemented into solar tracking systems.

The advent of online platforms and e-commerce will continue to aid wholesalers moving forward. Even so, direct manufacturer-to-consumer sales are set to rise as many markets seek ways to reduce costs and cut the middleman out entirely. Even so, reputable distributors will still thrive because of exceptional customer service and quick turnaround times. Competition will intensify with distributors servicing a saturated market. To be successful, distributors must differentiate themselves from competitors through value-added services (think broadening the range of fluid power equipment offered to serve as a one-stop shop for various downstream users and offering superior customer services). Smaller companies that do not have the capital resources to keep up in a saturated area may be forced to exit or be consolidated by a larger company.

industry_definition: Operators distribute fluid power equipment to manufacturers, mining companies and other users. The distributed equipment can be hydraulic or pneumatic, using liquid or gas to generate power and actuate machines and devices. Operators distribute fluid power pumps and motors, as well as parts and accessories such as valves.
key_trends: During the pandemic, sales from major markets fell, but the growth of e-commerce platforms provided a boost to distributors amid increasing competition. Possessing a website enables customers to browse products, make orders, complete payments, and reach out to customer service, all within a unified platform.

Consolidation activity continues to make waves among distributors despite lower profitability. Larger companies are acquiring smaller companies to expand their domestic footprint and extend their product offerings to remain competitive.

Licensing requirements vary based on the distributor's target market. Distributors selling exclusively to other businesses only need a wholesaler's license, whereas those engaged in both wholesale and retail sales require a retail tax license.

Though wholesalers don't directly receive government assistance, they can access support through different trade associations. Associations like the National Fluid Power Association and Fluid Power Distributors Association play a direct role in assisting wholesalers by advocating for fluid power technology.
Retail sales have been declining due to the nature of fluid power equipment. Clients generally opt for bulk purchases for cost efficiency instead of buying a few pieces from a retailer.

The Southwestern region of the United States, specifically Texas serves as a significant energy hub. Fluid power equipment plays a crucial role in performing diverse tasks associated with oil drilling in this area.

Automobile manufacturers use fluid power equipment to enhance brake systems. The Great Lakes are a pivotal hub for automobile manufacturing, granting distributors convenient access to a broad client base.
Wholesalers face external competition from direct-to-manufacturer sales. Even so, wholesalers pride themselves on customer service and quick turnaround times to attract clients.
No company holds a market share of more than 5.0%. Fluid power distribution is highly fragmented, with lower barriers of entry.
Some larger companies partake in consolidation. Applied Industrial Technologies, the largest distributor, has made multiple acquisitions over the years.

Purchase costs have remained relatively steady. While purchases can vary depending on downstream markets, equipment used for manufacturing, mining and extraction generates higher profit levels, reducing purchasing costs as a share of revenue.

market_segmentation.segment_description: Fluid power equipment is essential for manufacturing and mining

Retailers are looking to make a profit
Construction contractors use fluid power to aid equipment

demand_determinants.determinant_description: Manufacturers use fluid power technologies to generate and transmit power in many applications, like braking systems.

business_locations.location_description: The Southeast holds the largest number of fluid power equipment distributors because it has a significant presence in aerospace and defense, sheet metal and heavy equipment manufacturing.
The Southwest, particularly Texas, is involved in oil drilling and processing.
The Great Lakes region holds the second-largest number of distributors at around 12%.

regulations_points.regulation_description: Distributors that only sell to other businesses for resale require a wholesaler's license from the US Department of Revenue.
Companies are also subject to various occupational health and safety regulations.

barriers_points.barrier_description: The industry is in the decline stage of its life cycle.
The level of industry assistance is low and steady.
The competition level in the industry is high and steady.

factors_decreased_barrier: The capital intensity level is low.

basis_points.basis_description: Wholesalers face external competition from direct-to-manufacturer sales.
Wholesalers pride themselves on customer service and quick turnaround times to attract clients.
New entrants must price their products competitively to make a dent in the industry.
Many existing distributors have long-term contracts in place with suppliers.

concentration_points.concentration_description: The industry is fragmented and localized.
The majority of distributors are small and have less than 12 employees.
While acquisition activity is not rampant, larger companies are aware of the competitive advantage afforded by being in proximity to customers.

cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Commodity prices can impact profit since many of these tools are essential for mining and extraction.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: Distributors require a large workforce to handle warehouse operations.

volatility_points.volatility_title: The Pandemic Deters Investment in Machinery
volatility_points.volatility_description: The pandemic introduced economic uncertainty, causing many customers to hold back on buying new machinery.

technological_change_points.technological_change_title: FLUID POWER PUMPS, MOTORS AND PARTS ARE THE PRIMARY COMPONENTS
technological_change_points.technological_change_description: This segment consists of the main components of fluid power equipment.

FAQs.question: How have your sales been affected by the growth of online shopping?
FAQs.answer: Due to the specialized nature of industry products, sales have not been significantly affected by online shopping.

FAQs.question: How does your company maintain a competitive edge in an industry with many competitors?
FAQs.answer: Companies are increasingly seeking to increase their efficiency over their competitors through strategic acquisitions.

FAQs.question: Has your company explored growth opportunities via mergers or acquisitions?
FAQs.answer: Larger companies in this industry are engaging in significant acquisition activity as the industry continues to consolidate.

FAQs.question: How does your company negotiate favorable purchase costs with suppliers?
FAQs.answer: Purchase costs are by far the largest expense in this industry, so operators seek to cultivate relationships with manufacturers to ease these costs.

FAQs.question: How frequently does your company purchase new equipment?
FAQs.answer: Companies are increasingly purchasing new equipment to optimize their shipping and inventory processes.
